titleStmt.title: Several letters of great consequence intercepted by Colonel Milton, near Ruthyn in VVales, concerning Irish forces to be brought into England, with other matters of great consequence. Together with a letter sent out of Ireland, to Mr. Pierrepont a member of the House of Commons, concerning the passage, imprisonment, and enlargement of the Earl of Glamorgan: all which were read in the House of Commons. Ordered by the Commons assembled in Parliament, that these letters be forthwith printed and published. H. Elsynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: SEVERAL LETTERS Of great Con≈øequence INTERCEPTED BY Colonel Milton, neer Ruthyn IN VVALES, Concerning Iri≈øh Forces to be brought into England, and other matters of great con≈øequence.
Together with a LETTER ≈øent out of Ireland, to Mr. Pierrepont a Member of the Hou≈øe of Commons, concerning the Pa≈ø≈øage, Impri≈øonment, and Enlargement of the Earl of Glamorgan:
All which were Read in the Hou≈øe of COMMONS.
ORdered by the Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, That the≈øe Letters be forthwith Printed and Publi≈øhed.
H. El≈øynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.
London, Printed for Edw. Husband, Printer to the Honorable Hou≈øe of Commons, and are to be ≈øold at his Shop at the ≈øigne of the Golden Dragon in Fleet≈øtreet, neer the Inner-Temple. Feb. 17. 1645.

div.head: To the Honorable William Lenthal E≈øq Speaker in the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: I Acknowledge with all humble thankfulne≈øs, the favour of the Honourable Hou≈øe of Commons, in tru≈øting me with your Service in the≈øe parts, and hold it my duty, not onely to perform that tru≈øt to the uttermo≈øt of my power in action, but al≈øo upon all occa≈øions to repre≈øent unto you the ≈øtate of the Affairs here; in pur≈øuance whereof, I have now di≈øpatched Mr. Fogg my Chaplain with ≈øome Letters which I met withal here, who al≈øo can acquaint you with the cau≈øe and particular occurrents ≈øince my coming hither, and will readily return unto me what further Commands you ≈øhall plea≈øe to lay upon me. The main end of my coming hither was, to finde out the Lord St. Pauls Forces, and to prevent his conjunction with the Lord A≈øhley; but perceiving him to decline me, and to retreat to Fanru≈øt, being a Pa≈øs into Carnarvan≈øhire, where I am credibly informed he is now with his Forces: I have cho≈øen rather to ≈øtay here, then to advance any further toward him, he being Ma≈øter of that Pa≈øs, and ≈øo may ≈øecure him≈øelf: If I ≈øhould march up to him, my being here I hope will keep him from either joyning with A≈øhley, or any way annoy the Leaguer before Che≈øter; and withal, I am certainly informed that this Ca≈øtle is in a low condition, wanting both Ammunition and Fewel. The Governour before my coming hither, being gone to Conway for a ≈øupply of Powder, hoping that in ca≈øe I be not called away upon other occa≈øions toward Chester, unto which all my de≈øignes ≈øhalbe ≈øub≈øervient. I hope by Gods ble≈ø≈øing not to make any long work of it.

div.head: For His Highne≈ø≈øe the Duke of York.
div.p: HAving received intelligence of your being at Worcester, and a di≈øpatch now going to His Maje≈øty, I hold it my duty to acquaint Your Highne≈ø≈øe with a report brought hither, or perhaps framed here, That your intention is to come into this Kingdom, a thing ≈øo unprobable, that I can give no credit unto it; yet I hold it my duty as well to His Maje≈øty as Your Highne≈ø≈øe, to inform you, That as yet there is no Peace concluded here, and that thorough an accident lately faln out (wherein the Earl of Glamorgan hath a part) His Maje≈øties Affairs here, and all His Servants, are not onely upon very great uncertainty, but in apparant and continual danger of ≈øurpri≈øe and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, as well by the Iri≈øh as by the Covenanters in the North, and other parts of this Kingdom, all which is now adverti≈øed to His Maje≈øty, and therefore if any ≈øuch intention of Your Highne≈ø≈øe coming into this Kingdom ≈øhould be (which I take to be impo≈ø≈øible) I humbly offer, whether Your Highne≈ø≈øe may not hold it fit to expect His Maje≈øties further plea≈øure, which He may declare upon the knowledge He will receive of the ≈øtate of Things here, by the di≈øpatch that goes herewith before any ≈øuch dangerous adventure of Your Highne≈ø≈øe Per≈øon, as You mu≈øt in ≈øuch ca≈øe undergo in Your coming, and during Your Highne≈ø≈øe abode here. I humbly be≈øeech Your Highne≈ø≈øe to pardon the impertinence of this fir≈øt addre≈ø≈øe to Your Highne≈ø≈øe from

closer.dateline: His Maje≈øties Ca≈øtle of Dublin, the 19. of Jan. 1645.
closer.signed:
Your Highne≈ø≈øe mo≈øt faithful and mo≈øt humble Servant
‚Ä¢ rmond.

div.head:
To his much honoured and worthy friend Sir John Wats Knight, Governour of Cher ‚Ä¢
Ca≈øtle.
div.p: I Thank you for this, and all other courte≈øies; be plea≈øed to read, and then to Seal this inclo≈øed, and you ≈øhall thereby under≈øtand, all I am able to ≈øay of this great bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, which God Almighty pro≈øper.

Col. Butler, who will be with you at or before this Letter, will import all the News of Ireland: He is a ≈øervant in ordinary of the Queens. And ≈øo be≈øeeching God to ble≈ø≈øe you, I remain, Noble Governour,

closer.signed: Your affectionate friend and ≈øervant, Io. Eborac.

div.head: To the Right Wor≈øhipful, his worthy Friend, Ma≈øter Doctor Lloyd Warden of Ruthin.
div.p: MA≈øter Doctor, I thank you for your Letter, and will ≈øatisfie the Bearer: And I be≈øeech you to return the≈øe Letter, to the Noble Governour, The Duke of York, to be ≈øent him, as ≈øoon as may well be; for in Ireland they will not be gain-≈øaid, but that he is at Ludlow. The Boat ≈øtayeth, I thank you good Doctor, and am

div.head: To the Right Honorable the Lord A≈øhley.
div.p:
YOur Lord≈øhips Letter of the 12. of January, I received late at night, the 24 of the ≈øame moneth. I have communicated to the Lord Byron, the Lord Marque≈ø≈øe of Ormond
his Letter of the 12. of Decemb. and by this time (not ≈øooner) the Lord Byrons An≈øwer is at Dublin, which I ≈øent by his Lord≈øhips Chaplain. It implyed ≈øome fears of holding out Che≈øter, thus long: Col. Butler tells me even now, that the men and ≈øhipping are ≈øtill ready in Ireland, though retarded hitherto by rea≈øon of this di≈øtraction; which ≈øithence Tue≈øday la≈øt, is ≈øo compo≈øed, that the Earl of Glamorgan is out upon Bayl of ≈øix or eight Noble men, whereof the Lord Marque≈ø≈øe of Clenrickard is one. From the Lord Lieutenant I have received no An≈øwer in writing as yet (though my Letters to his Excellency were many ≈øithence the fir≈øt of January) nor from the Lord Digby any more to the purpo≈øe, then this enclo≈øed.

There is, Noble Lord, no relyings upon the≈øe Iri≈øh Forces for this Service, though if they come, they ≈øhall be carefully tran≈øpo≈øed to ≈øuch a Rendezvouz, as I ≈øhall hear is mo≈øt fitting for the pa≈ø≈øage of your Lord≈øhips Army: And for that end, your Lord≈øhip ≈øhall ≈øurely be punctually informed of their landing, and condition.

In the mean time, it is fit your Lord≈øhip ≈øhould under≈øtand, that under Colonel Gilbert Byron, the Lord of St. Paul is in the≈øe parts in the head of 600 (as he ≈øaith) but I beleeve of 500 Hor≈øe and Foot, good men and well Armed, to be directed and imployed by your Lord≈øhip. Next that, that Lieut. Col. Roger Morton is landed with a peece of a Regiment (≈øome 160 as Col. Butler tells me) of the Lord Digbies rais'd in Ireland of Engli≈øh, and ≈øome Lorainne≈øes, and he will be able to make it up 200 upon his own credit (a Commi≈ø≈øioner of Array and Peace in this County) and will be, after a day or two his refre≈øhment, at your Lord≈øhips di≈øpo≈øe.

I conceive your Lord≈øhip will receive better Information then I can give you, of the Forces that our Garri≈øons are able to afford, from the worthy Governour of Cherb. But I have it from good and knowing hands, that the Armed and
Fighting men in Che≈øter are above 4000, whereof many may i≈ø≈øue forth. I pray God heartily (as I have cau≈øe) to ble≈ø≈øe and pro≈øper your Lord≈øhips honourable de≈øigne: and de≈øire your Lord≈øhip to e≈øteem of me, as of one, who hath long loved your Lord≈øhip, and may truely write my≈øelf,

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt affectionate and humble ≈øervant, Ioh. Eborac.

postscript.p: I have imported your Lord≈øhips Letter, and Sir John Wats to Col. Gilbert Byron, to be ≈øent to Chester.

div.p: I Give you very many humble thanks for your obliging Letter by Ma≈øter Moor: I have likewi≈øe ≈øent yours to the Marque≈ø≈øe of Ormond; and I am glad to finde there, that you do not take the Alarm at my Lord of Glamorgans commitment ≈øo hot, as upon it to de≈øpair of the relief of Chester; which, though it hath been ≈øomewhat retarded by it, yet I make little que≈øtion now, but it will go on ≈øpeedily and effectually: And of this I de≈øire you to certifie my L. Byron,

closer.signed: Your Graces mo≈øt affectionate humble ≈øervant, George Digby.

div.head: For the Honourable William Pierpoint E≈øquire.
div.p:
I Send you herewith another copy of the Articles taken in the Bi≈øhop of Tuam's Pocket, becau≈øe we finde that many of our Letters do mi≈øcarry; and we are not in ca≈øe to ≈øend expre≈ø≈øes till the Ship with the Money come to us: Her ≈øtay is a very great prejudice to the Service; for if ≈øhe had been here, we had prevailed with the Briti≈øh to ≈øend a 1000 men into Connaught, and you will perceive by the inclo≈øed from the Pre≈øident there, what he would expect to do if he had them. We thought it was of concernment, to let the good party at Dublin ≈øee how they were bought and ≈øold; and therefore ≈øent ≈øome Copies of the inclo≈øed Articles to them, who made ≈øuch an uproar:
That the Lord Digby di≈øclaimed the thing, and ≈øaid, The King would not yeeld to them to ≈øave his Crown, and his life; and that if any ≈øuch thing were gotten, it was procured ≈øurrepticiou≈øly; and therefore accu≈øed the Earl of Glamorgan of Trea≈øon, and accordingly he was committed the 26 of the la≈øt to the Ca≈øtle of Dublin. This in all appearance was done to pacifie the people; for a friend writes that he might have been relea≈øed of his clo≈øe impri≈øonment within two dayes after, if he would have acknowledged that he proceeded in it without Warrant, but he ju≈øtifies the Act, and ≈øo remains a pri≈øoner.

I have written to you ≈øeveral times, that the Derry cannot be ≈øecured till there be ≈øome power to di≈øplace Malignant Captains of that Regiment; and if the Scotch Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhould now come, the Ordinance is expired the third of this Moneth. I hope you are providing of a Deputy, who may ea≈øily cure all the di≈øtempers of this Army.

I wrote to you formetly, that I was going into Connaught, and had been gone before this, but the Fro≈øt and Snow was ≈øo great, that I could not well travel. This day, God plea≈øed, I begin my journey, and do hope, God a≈ø≈øi≈øting, to make it u≈øeful to the publike.

I beleeve a long Letter will be trouble≈øome to you, and therefore I will not detain you longer from reading the Pre≈øident of Connaughts, which hath in it very good news: And ≈øo conclude my ≈øelf to be

postscript.p: We ≈øhall endeavour to get 1000 to go in to Connaught, though the Money be not come.

div.head: Prodromus Papae.
div.p: This was ≈øent in the Packet with the precedent Letter.THe Stile, Audience and Sub≈øtance of the Oration of the Popes Nuncio at Kilkenny Dominus Iohannes Bapti≈øta Renuccius.

p.hi: Dominus Archicopi≈øcopus & princeps Farmanuz, apud Confederatos Hiberniae Catholicos Extraordinarius Apo≈øtolicus Nuncius,

div.p: Had Audience at the Ca≈øtle of Kilkenny the 19. of November, 1645. where he ≈øhewed his Commi≈ø≈øion, and declared the Rea≈øons of his coming, which was onely to e≈øtabli≈øh according to his power,

list.item: 3 And la≈øtly, to ≈øerve their Prince and Soveraign.

div.p: Which he did expre≈ø≈øe with a great deal of ≈øence and feeling in the≈øe words, viz.
Et ≈øereni≈øsimo vestro principi meip≈øum devoveo. Clapping his hand upon his Bre≈øt,
But yet, that for their Religion they ≈øhould fight & maintain it again≈øt all the world. He ≈øaid High Ma≈ø≈øe in the Church of Kilkenny upon Saint Andrews day.
